name: International Rescue Committee
mission: The International Rescue Committee (IRC) responds to the world's worst humanitarian crises, helping to restore health, safety, education, economic well being, and power to people devastated by conflict and disaster. Founded in 1933 at the call of Albert Einstein, the IRC is at work in over 40 countries and 26 U.S. cities helping people to survive, reclaim control of their future and strengthen their communities.
theoryOfChange: The International Rescue Committee (IRC) has a published 'Outcomes and Evidence Framework' (OEF) which serves as a strategic framework for guiding program decisions and designing effective programs. This interactive tool delivers key information on outcomes related to health, safety, education, economic wellbeing, and power through theories of change that demonstrate how to achieve these outcomes. The IRC systematically uses theories of change in all its new project designs to ensure outcome-driven and evidence-based projects. The OEF also includes core indicators to measure the change in outcomes over time. Additionally, the IRC utilizes an 'IMPACT Program Quality Framework' which defines program quality through six principles and supports the goals of their broader 'Strategy100'.

zakatClaimEvidence: The IRC has worked with Islamic scholars and has received a fatwa confirming the IRC as a legitimate recipient of Zakat. We have launched a pilot Fund for Ramadan this year. IRC will accept Zakat each year during Ramadan, starting in February 2026, the month of Ramadan. (Source: https://www.rescue.org/)

all_citations.claim: The IRC holds a 97.0/100 rating and focuses on safety, empowerment, and economic wellbeing.
The organization reported total revenue of $1,341,268,864.
IRC programs track metrics such as average increase in credit scores and liquid assets for clients.
The organization monitors the average increase in liquid assets for program participants.
Impact evaluations show improvements in community meetings and villager ratings of service quality.
all_citations.source_name: Report: Participatory Development in Fragile and Conflict-affected Contexts

all_citations.claim: The organization provides various donation options for humanitarian relief.

baseline_narrative.amal_score_rationale: The IRC earns a high overall score due to its massive operational scale, high transparency, and direct provision of essential services in urgent humanitarian contexts.
areas_for_improvement: Relatively high cost per beneficiary compared to smaller-scale local interventions.
Maintaining a working capital reserve of 2.4 months, which provides a limited buffer for a billion-dollar global operation.

dimension_explanations.alignment: The organization shows high alignment for donors seeking to address urgent humanitarian needs, and its Zakat-eligible status makes it a strong fit for Muslim donors [1][6]. With a long track record of managing $1,341,268,864 in annual revenue, it offers high data confidence and reliability [2].
dimension_explanations.impact: The IRC demonstrates high impact through direct service provision, maintaining an 87.7% program expense ratio and achieving measurable outcomes in participant credit scores and liquid assets [1][3][4]. Its programs are backed by rigorous impact evaluations, such as the Tuungane 2 study which tracked improvements in community service quality [5].

baseline_narrative.headline: The International Rescue Committee provides life-saving assistance and long-term recovery support to people displaced by humanitarian crises worldwide.
strengths: High program expense ratio of 87.7%, ensuring the vast majority of funds reach those in need.
Exceptional fundraising efficiency with a cost of only $0.06 per $1 raised.
Strong financial health and accountability with a Charity Navigator score of 97.0/100.
baseline_narrative.summary: The International Rescue Committee (IRC) helps individuals affected by conflict and disaster to survive and rebuild their lives through programs focused on safety, empowerment, and economic wellbeing [1][5]. In the most recent fiscal period, the organization reported a total revenue of $1,341,268,864 to fund its global operations [2].

alignment.improvement: Further <cite id="22">expanding services to underserved geographies</cite> with limited nonprofit coverage could maximize alignment scores.

credibility.explanation: The IRC is a highly credible institution with <cite id="11">20/20 BBB standards met</cite>, a <cite id="14">Platinum Candid seal</cite>, and <cite id="19">audited financial statements</cite> that confirm the integrity of its billion-dollar budget.

impact.explanation: Impact is driven by a <cite id="4">87.7% program ratio</cite> and a <cite id="20">98/100 Impact beacon score</cite> from Charity Navigator, supported by a <cite id="21">strong theory of change</cite>.
impact.improvement: The IRC could <cite id="17">build reserves toward a higher target range</cite> to improve long-term financial resilience against revenue volatility.

rich_narrative.headline: The International Rescue Committee provides life-saving assistance and long-term recovery support to people displaced by humanitarian crises worldwide.

ideal_donor_profile.best_for_summary: Best for donors who want to fulfill zakat through a high-capacity, globally recognized institution capable of delivering aid in the world's most dangerous conflict zones.
donor_motivations: Want to ensure their zakat reaches the most vulnerable in Gaza, Yemen, and Afghanistan
Value extreme financial efficiency with over 94% of funds reaching programs
Prefer organizations with a long, 90-year track record of stability
Trust third-party verifications like Charity Navigator and BBB
giving_considerations: Large-scale operations mean donations are part of a massive global pool
Focus is on high-intensity humanitarian crises rather than small-scale community projects
The organization operates with lean reserves to maximize immediate aid delivery
ideal_donor_profile.not_ideal_for: Donors seeking to support small, grassroots organizations or those who prefer funding local US-based community centers.

impact_evidence.evidence_grade_explanation: The IRC tracks <cite id="24">8 distinct outcome metrics</cite> and publishes <cite id="12">rigorous impact evaluations</cite> of its major programs.
impact_evidence.theory_of_change_summary: The IRC uses a research-backed framework to ensure that interventions in health, safety, and education lead to measurable improvements in the lives of the displaced.
impact_evidence.why_evidence_matters: Evidence ensures that billion-dollar budgets are not just spent, but are effectively changing lives in fragile contexts.

long_term_outlook.room_for_funding_explanation: Global humanitarian needs in Gaza, Sudan, and Ukraine continue to outpace the IRC's current funding levels.

organizational_capacity.geographic_reach: Asia, Europe, Africa, South America, United States

strengths.detail: The IRC maintains a <cite id="4">87.7% program expense ratio</cite> and an incredibly low fundraising cost of <cite id="9">$0.06 per $1 raised</cite>.
The organization holds a <cite id="10">97/100 overall score from Charity Navigator</cite> and <cite id="11">meets all 20 BBB Standards for Charity Accountability</cite>.
Rigorous evaluations of programs like Tuungane 2 show a <cite id="12">0.47 increase in community-CODESA meetings</cite> over control groups, demonstrating effective local governance support.

strengths_deep_dive: The IRC's operational strength is rooted in its ability to combine massive financial scale with high-fidelity program execution. With <cite id="13">35 board members</cite> providing oversight and a <cite id="14">Platinum Seal of Transparency from Candid</cite>, the organization demonstrates a commitment to institutional excellence. Their ability to manage <cite id="15">$436,989,489 in total grants</cite>—including significant foreign grants to local partners—allows them to scale impact rapidly during acute emergencies while maintaining a <cite id="16">97% independent board</cite> to ensure ethical stewardship.
rich_narrative.summary: founded in 1933 at the call of Albert Einstein, the International Rescue Committee (IRC) has evolved into a global humanitarian powerhouse that <cite id="1">helps people affected by humanitarian crises to survive, recover and rebuild</cite>. The organization operates at a massive scale, reporting <cite id="2">$1,341,268,864 in total revenue</cite> to support its mission across more than 40 countries. The IRC's model is built on direct service delivery, focusing on critical sectors such as <cite id="3">malnutrition treatment, health care, and emergency response</cite>. Their financial efficiency is a hallmark of their operations, maintaining a <cite id="4">87.7% program expense ratio</cite>, which ensures that the vast majority of resources are deployed directly to the field. For Muslim donors, the IRC offers a structured <cite id="5">zakat-eligible giving pathway</cite>, directing funds toward eligible categories including the poor (fuqara) and needy (masakin) in high-need regions like <cite id="6">Gaza, Yemen, and Afghanistan</cite>. Beyond immediate relief, the IRC invests in long-term economic empowerment, as evidenced by programs that helped participants achieve an <cite id="7">average credit score of 684</cite> and an <cite id="8">average increase in liquid assets of $1,381.80</cite>.
